newsitem.title: USA: Stocks hit new record, interest rates tumble.
newsitem.headline: Stocks hit new record, interest rates tumble.

text.p: Stocks surged to a new record Wednesday as optimism over the economy and the balanced budget pact drove bonds higher and pushed long-term interest rates to their lowest levels in nearly 18 months.
The dollar rose to a new 2-1/2-month high against the Japanese yen, and gasoline prices rallied to their highest level in six months.
The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 80.36 points to 8,254.89, the third consecutive record for the blue-chip average and its sixth new high in the last seven sessions.
Other major averages also set records, and rising issues swamped decliners on the New York Stock Exchange as the relatively narrow rally of recent sessions spread to the broader market.
The gains again came on the back of a strong advance in the bond market that pushed interest rates broadly lower.

"What justifies this market is lower interest rates, and there's a real perception that we're looking at a long bond that could be headed to 6 percent," said Richard Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker.
"If you believe that, then its certainly possible to be bullish on stocks."

The long bond, the benchmark 30-year Treasury, rose 26/32, or $8.13 on a $1,000 bond, lowering its yield to 6.33 percent, the lowest since Feb. 16, 1996, from 6.39 percent Tuesday. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions.
The euphoric atmosphere on Wall Street has come as investors have been treated to strong corporate earnings and falling interest rates, while inflation remains under control.
Americans continue to plough huge amounts of cash into mutual funds, most of them stock funds, creating demand for stocks and helping to fuel the rally.

According to the Investment Company Institute, which monitors fund activity, $19.91 billion flowed into mutual funds in June, and while that was down from $33.52 billion in May, it put total combined assets of the nation's mutual funds above $4 trillion for the first time.

The dollar edged higher vs. the yen Wednesday, aided by concern about a weak Japanese economy and fears of renewed tension in U.S.-Japan trade relations. The dollar settled at 118.41 yen, up from 118.35 yen late Tuesday.

At the New York Mercantile Exchange, worries over tightening inventories boosted gasoline for August delivery to 69.90 cents a gallon, up 3.43 cents a gallon and its highest settlement since January 10.
Overseas, Britain's FTSE 100 closed at 4,927.3, up 50.7 points, or 1.04 percent. Tokyo's 225-stock Nikkei average closed at 20,212.82, down 189.92 points, or 0.93 percent.
